paragraphs.name: de09
paragraphs.text: As the Authors Guild’s Gleick points out, Google started Books with a “better ask forgiveness than permission” attitude that’s common today in the world of startups. In a sense, the company behaved like the Uber of intellectual property — a kind of read-sharing service — while expecting to be seen the way it saw itself, as a beneficent pantheon of wizards serving the entire human species. It was naive, and the stubborn opposition it aroused came as a shock.

virtuals.subtitle: In 2013 I wrote a dissertation on possible legal solutions to the orphan works issue. It briefly discusses Google Books, as well as meme…

paragraphs.text: Thanks for this interesting piece, Scott. I’ve always felt that Google Books could have been something much greater, and I do wonder if some compromise between Google and the Authors’ Guild could have led to better outcomes for all concerned.

paragraphs.text: If you need it — really, aren’t All Things Google about want, not need? — Google Books has its own search bar now. They changed their listing to highlight the most-used (probably meaning Best Monetized) links, focus more attention on the products they make, and took some things off the list to their own locations.

paragraphs.text: Good followup piece, Scott. The short answer to your basic question is that Google offered the world a huge gift much greater in power than the small benefit they would receive back for it. And like many good things in life this act of goodness was spoiled by a small number of people who wanted more. In this case the Authors Guild. The Guild is made…

paragraphs.text: I just finished a book of quotations (“Star Wars Wisdom”) after spending 20 years compiling, and editing down, a compendium of enlightening quotes from numerous authors. These are exactly the uses envisioned for https://www.hathitrust.org/htrc . I don’t see it mentioned anywhere in the essay or in the other comments, so here you go.

paragraphs.text: I’ve always thought that Internet Archive was in a much better position to become the universal library.
Googles focus seems to be more on organizing and presenting useful information instead of being a library and they have the most useful books in their collection. There is little reason to add more.

paragraphs.text: Given the (stupidly short sighted) attitude of Authors Guild I’m not surprised Google have given this project lower priority. Still — it’s a great project, for which I am thankful almost everyday. Together with Open Library I have access to a world class digital library service in rural Spain.
